passages.text: **Rmb8bn recurring profit scale in '25E at 30% NPM:** Longfor's model is sustainable,in our view: i) Rmb8/10bn recurring profits in '25/27E (10% CAGR) at 50% GPM/ 30%NPM; ii) 10% rental growth from 10 new malls in '25E & same-store sale/footfall+3%/8%yoy in 1H; iii) +ve OCF for all biz units (1H25/25E: Rmb2/10bn+ inflow); iv)lower debt('24/25/28E: Rmb176/145/100bn) & costs (3.58%); v) credit loans (1H25:16%; 21: 55% of debts) largely replaced by asset-backed operating loans (1H25:Rmb87bn). We expect its profit scale to bottom in transitional '25E on de-stocking (0-5% GPM) & pick up in '26E. We believe Longfor deserves higher valuation multiple on more sustainable profits. Affirm Buy (70% NAV disc, 5.8% yield at 30% payout).New TP HK$15.8 (+33%) on narrower 60% NAV disc (prev. 70%) on higher B/S strength.

**Recurring biz: 10% profit CAGR** - Longfor's 1H recurring profit +3%yoy (Rmb4bn):i) malls rentals (76% GPM): 1H profit +3%yoy (excl. AEls: est. +9%); same-store sales+3%yoy; 10 new malls in '25E (89 opened) could bring Rmb1bn revenue; AEls in CQ & Suzhou to boost Rmb0.12bn rentals in '26E; ii) serviced apartment (81.3% GPM):revenue -5% yoy but profit at growth on exit of projects at loss; iii) prop mgmt. (28%GPM): -4%yoy on exit of inefficient projects & value-added services; cost controls via digitalization; iv) construction (42% GPM) +65%yoy; Rmb2.2bn new contracts.

**Optimizing very sustainable debt profile** - i) reducing debt to c.Rmb100bn by '28E('25E: Rmb145bn; 87% from bank; peak in '22: Rmb212bn) by +OCF of all biz (1H/25E: Rmb2.2/ 10bn); ii) replacing credit loans (1H25: 16%; 21: 55% of debts) by asset-backed operating loans (1H25: Rmb93bn; '25E: Rmb100bn) with avg 11-years tenor; iv) 3.58% funding costs ('24: 4.0%); v) no offshore debts maturity before '27E.

**Sales: Rm125bn resources in 2H** - 1H sales -32%yoy (Rmb35bn; attr. Rmb24.5bn).Longfor plans Rmb125bn resources for 2H. 1H DP GPM at 0.2% but new lands GPM at 15%. Longfor added 5 projects in 8M25 for Rmb1.7bn cost (Rmb5.8bn resources).

**Profit: Weak 1H on strong IP profit but DP loss well expected** - 1H25 core profit -71yoy to Rmb1.38bn, aligned with its profit alert: i) recurring rental & services profit Rmb4bn (+3%yoy) offset by Rmb2.6bn DP loss (Rmb106bn unbook); ii) IP rentals +3%yoy on AEls; ii) property mgmt -4%yoy on exit of projects at loss; construction +60% yoy. B/S: 51% gearing; less debt. Interim DPS Rmb 7 cents (34% payout).

We attended a longfor's 1H25 analyst results meeting. Key takeaways are as follows:
Prioritize debt optimization through operating cashflow to ensure safeness
- (1) Lower debt scale
- Dec'25E target Rmb145bn (-Rmb31bn yoy), including c.Rmb100bn long-tenure IP operating loan or rental apartment loan, c.Rmb20bn construction loan, and c.Rmb25bn credit-based financing
- Long-term comfortable with c.Rmb100bn total debt scale
- (2) Change to project-based long-duration bank loan, from credit-based financing
- Bank loan at 87% of total debt by 1H25 (Dec'24: 83%; Dec'21: 45%)
- IP operating loan added Rmb10bn in 1H25 to Rmb870bn, including Rmb5bn from higher LTV, and Rmb5bn from new malls
- (3) Currency matching: remains 14% of non-Rmb debt and zero non-Rmb debt exposure after full hedging
- (4) Lengthen debt tenor to 10.95 years (e.g., IP operating loan usually 15 years), with 49% of debt maturing after 5 years
- (5) Lower finance cost to 3.58% by 1H25
Profit scale: Short- term continued pressure from property development; mid- long term growth from operational & services business

- C1 (Property Development): Destocking cycle could last for a few more years with continued drag on earnings. DP GPM see further pressure due to relatively low unbooked margin (Citi est. 0-5%) and destocking (possible loss-making for certain inventory sales). That said, new land GPM is at c.15%, offer room for gradual recovery in the future.
- C2-C5 (Operational and Services businesses): Rmb8bn profit in 2024, expect some growth in 2025, and aims Rmb10bn profit in 3-5 years, with 50%+ GPM and around 30% NPM.
- C2 (mall): aims 10% rental growth in 2025; plans around 10 new openings each year

- Mgmt explains the slower growth in 1H25 (rental +5%) was mainly due to c.Rmb200mn rental loss from AEl works undergoing at 26 malls (e.g., full renovation, underground supermarket repositioning; CQ Beicheng mall have c.Rmb100mn -ve impact).
- i.e., 1H25 rental would have +9% if there were no such AEls.
- Mgmt expects less drag in 2H25E, and to harvest the positive results in 2026E (eyes double-digit footfall & tenant sales increase post upgrades).
- It plans to open 11 new malls in 2025E, and around 10 new malls each year in the near future, which should contribute Rmb1bn+ additional inorganic rental income growth.

- C3 (asset mgmt, mainly rental apartment): Not much revenue growth due to termination of certain non-core or low-quality projects (e.g., hotel, projects signs years ago with less preferable terms), while profitability should continue to improve with +ve OCF.
- C4 (property mgmt): aims resuming growth from 2H25.
- 1H drop was due to: (1) withdrawal from projects with low mgmt fee cap; (2) exit certain low-efficient VAS; (3) higher opex and digitalization cost; (4) provision on receivables.
- It has c.500 pipeline projects (+20% vs. current 2,200 managed), which could contribute 40msm GFA in the next 3-years (+10% vs current c.400msm managed).

- Future expansion will focus on key 50-60 cities, services with entry barriers, and major 2B customers (c.100 strategic customers across its C1-C5 business, with 40% repurchase rate of its services).

- Positive operating cashflow: targets Rmb10bn in 2025E (1H25: Rmb2.2bn; 2024: Rmb6bn), with each of the C2-C5 business itself runs under positive OCF. It expects to unleash increasing OCF from C2 (mall), on growing rentals and less capex, amounting to
has Rmb8bn sales from completed homes (23% of contracted sales), and revitalized Rmb12.8bn existing sellable resources amid destocking efforts.

We have a short- term upside view on Longfor. We believe Longfor deserves a higher valuation multiple on more sustainable profits, with Rmb8/10bn recurring profits in 2025/27E (c.10% CAGR) at 50% GPM/ 30% NPM. We expect its profit scale to bottom in transitional '25E on de- stocking (0- 5% GPM) & pick up in '26E.
Spread 99pp Current Price and expected returns (upside/downside) as of 29 Aug 2025
ASP growth \(3\%\) higher than our base case \(45\%\) targeted NAV discount
Our general physical market assumptions \(50\%\) targeted NAV discount
ASP growth \(10\%\) weaker than our base case \(55\%\) targeted NAV discount

Founded in 1994, Longfor started its property development business in Chongqing, which is the hometown of the founder and Chairwoman Madam Wu. In 1997, Longfor commenced development of its first property project in Chongqing - Longhu Garden Nanyuan. Later, Longfor developed Longfor Garden Xiyuan, Fragrant Forest (one of the most reputable high- end villa projects in Chongqing), Crystal Town, Blue Lake County (the biggest pure villa/townhouse project in Chongqing), Chongqing Fairy Castle, Hill of Good Hope, Bamboo Grove (one of the most successful high- rise/townhouse complex projects in Chongqing) and many other projects. Besides these well- known residential projects in Chongqing, Longfor also developed many commercial property projects in Chongqing, including a popular shopping mall - North Paradise Walk and West Paradise Walk. Longfor has developed the ability to offer a wide spectrum of high- quality property products in Chongqing, including villas, townhouses, high- rise apartments, shopping malls, offices etc, which gives it a broad customer base and diversifies risks.

We rate Longfor shares Buy. Longfor's model is sustainable, in our view: i) Rmb8/9bn recurring profits in '24/25E (10- 15% CAGR) at 50% GPM/ 30% NPM; ii) est. 6- 7% NPI yield on costs of its malls exceed 4% finance cost; iii) 10% rental growth from 11 new malls in '25E & same- store sale/ rental +7%/2%yoy in '24; iv) +ve OCF for all biz units (24/25E: Rmb6.4/20bn+ inflow); v) DP scale- down matched with capex cut ('24/25E: Rmb50/20bn); vi) lower debt scale ('24/25E: Rmb176/140bn) & costs; vii) credit loans ('24: 17%; 21: 55% of debts) almost replaced by asset- backed operating loans ('24/25E: Rmb76/90bn). We expect its profit scale to bottom in transitional '25E for de- stocking at 0- 5% GPM but pick up in '26E. We believe Longfor deserves a higher valuation multiple on higher sustainable profits.

Our target price of HK\$15.8 for Longfor is set at a 60% discount to our FY25E NAV of HK\$39.6. Our 60% NAV discount is set at - 2.5SD to the historical mean, which we believe is warranted for quality players with clear and balanced outlook and deep penetration in high tier cities. We believe Longfor's core competencies, including its geographical framework, product positioning, professional management and low- cost financing, should continue to underpin its balanced development. Discount to NAV is the most widely used method to value Hong Kong and China property stocks. NAV measures the value of a stock based on the market value of its assets; for a property company those would be its development and investment properties. The NAV discount is then adjusted for the "realizability" of those assets and growth potential in that NAV; the more realizable the NAV is, or the larger the growth potential the NAV carries, the lower the discount to NAV should be.

Longfor is exposed to property markets and the primary land market in mainland China. The most notable downside risks to Longfor are economic and policy- related. With regard to economic risks, we think any weaker- than- expected GDP growth for the Chinese and/or global economies, and the risk of a hard landing in the domestic economy, could negatively affect buyers' sentiment toward China's property markets, which could render our revenue and earnings estimates for Longfor optimistic. In addition, any stronger- than- expected pickup in inflation could result in a sharp rise in interest rates, which would affect affordability for homebuyers. On the policy front, any further tightening measures or policy changes by the central government with regard to mortgage applications and approvals, project financing, and property pre- sales could adversely affect the bottom lines and cash flows of property developers, and homebuyer sentiment. These risks could impede the stock from achieving our target price.

Citi Research stock recommendations include an investment rating and an optional risk rating to highlight high risk stocks. Risk rating takes into account both price volatility and fundamental criteria. Stocks will either have no risk rating or a High risk rating assigned.

Investment Ratings: Citi Research investment ratings are Buy, Neutral and Sell. Our ratings are a function of analyst expectations of expected total return ("ETR") and risk. ETR is the sum of the forecast price appreciation (or depreciation) plus the dividend yield for a stock within the next 12 months. The target price is based on a 12 month time horizon. The Investment rating definitions are: Buy (1) ETR of 15% or more or 25% or more for High risk stocks; and Sell (3) for negative ETR. Any covered stock not assigned a Buy or a Sell is a Neutral (2). For stocks rated Neutral (2), if an analyst believes that there are insufficient valuation drivers and/or investment catalysts to derive a positive or negative investment view, they may elect with the approval of Citi Research management not to assign a target price and, thus, not derive an ETR. Citi Research may suspend its rating and target price and assign "Rating Suspended" status for regulatory and/or internal policy reasons. Citi Research may also suspend its rating and target price and assign "Under Review" status for other exceptional circumstances (e.g. lack of information critical to the analyst's thesis, trading suspension) affecting the company and/or trading in the company's securities. In both such situations, the rating and target price will show as "—" and "—" respectively in the rating history price chart. Prior to 11 April 2022 Citi Research assigned "Under Review" status to both situations and prior to 11 Nov 2020 only in exceptional circumstances. As soon as practically possible, the analyst will publish a note re- establishing a rating and investment thesis. Investment ratings are determined by the ranges described above at the time of initiation of coverage, a change in investment and/or risk rating, or a change in target price (subject to limited management discretion). At times, the expected total returns may fall outside of these ranges because of market price movements and/or other short- term volatility or trading patterns. Such interim deviations will be permitted but will become subject to review by Research Management. Your decision to buy or sell a security should be based upon your personal investment objectives and should be made only after evaluating the stock's expected performance and risk.

Catalyst Watch and STV Upside/Downside calls: Citi Research may also include a Catalyst Watch or STV Upside or Downside call to indicate the analyst expects the share price to rise (fall) in absolute terms over a specified period of 30 or 90 days in

reaction to one or more specific near- term catalysts or events impacting the company or the market. A Catalyst Watch will be published when Analyst confidence is high that an impact to share price will occur; it will be a STV when confidence level is moderate. A Catalyst Watch or STV Upside/Downside call will automatically expire at the end of the specified 30/90 day period. The Catalyst Watch will also be automatically removed if share price performance (calculated at market close) exceeds \(15\%\) against the direction of the call (unless over- ridden by the analyst). The analyst may also remove a Catalyst Watch or STV call prior to the end of the specified period in a published research note. A Catalyst Watch/STV Upside or Downside call may be different from and does not affect a stock's fundamental equity rating, which reflects a longer- term total absolute return expectation. For purposes of FINRA ratings- distribution- disclosure rules, a Catalyst Watch/STV Upside call corresponds to a buy recommendation and a Catalyst Watch/STV Downside call corresponds to a sell recommendation. Any stock not assigned to a Catalyst Watch Upside, Catalyst Watch Downside, STV Upside, or STV Downside call is considered Catalyst Watch/STV No View. For purposes of FINRA ratings distribution- disclosure rules, we correspond Catalyst Watch/STV No View to Hold in our ratings distribution table for our Catalyst Watch/STV Upside/Downside rating system. However, we reiterate that we do not consider No View to be a recommendation. For all Catalyst Watch/STV Upside/Downside calls, risk exists that the catalyst(s) and associated share- price movement will not materialize as expected.
